newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end higher in day of political drama.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end higher in day of political drama.

text.p: Blue chips at Bombay exchanges closed near the day's highs on Tuesday as domestic funds and some foreign players bought on dips during a day of wild swings wrought by the country's political crisis, dealers said.

"There has been a lot of buying by local institutions at lower prices," said Sanjeev Choithani, chief dealer at brokers Pashupati Advani. Buying was seen after the Bombay index on Monday suffered its fourth largest plunge ever of 310 points.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's 10-month old minority coalition government faces a confidence vote by April 11 after the Congress party on Sunday withdrew its crucial support.

"Our basic view is that the budget will remain intact," said Ajit Dayal, managing director of Quantum Financial Services which advises foreign and domestic clients. "By and large there'll be no changes."

Analysts pinned hopes on parliament passing the 1997/98 (April-March) budget regardless of the political crisis. "There might be minor changes but we're hopeful the budget will go through,"said Vinay Motwani at brokerage KBS Capital Management
The ruling coalition needs the support of lawmakers from the Congress party or the main opposition, Bharatiya Janata Party to ensure passage of the budget.
"The budget would not be possible before the confidence vote," BJP vice-president K.R. Malkani told Reuters. "I don't see how Congress or the BJP will agree with that."

But it could be considered later, Malkani said. "The government has to approach us then we can consider the matter," he said. "Let them convene a meeting. Let them do it properly," BJP president L.K. Advani told Reuters at the party office.

A spokesman for Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's United Front alliance said the coalition was exploring ways of ensuring passage of the budget before the test vote. "We are making an effort," spokesman Jaipal Reddy said.
The NSE index rose 0.30 percent at 971.15 provisional close.
